instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message:
I absolutely hate these boards. Not sure where to start?

i have taken some voltages:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> 3.26v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H_LDO</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.31v
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_S4SW</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> 1.06v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.58v

inspected under microscope nothing unusual.
tried the pram nvram etc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message:
You get even S0 voltages, so cannot be 0 Ampers drawn from charger.
Did you check for USB activity?
Any history available?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message: If VCore is present, no way it's zero amp draw. This sounds like a dead CPU btw. Def check for USB activity of any kind.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message:
i was testing s0 and found the weirdest thing. checking s0 lines and checked <SIGNAL>PP5VS0_BOOT</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C7520</CAPACITOR> pin 1 measures 5v but on pin 2 i got 9.80v!!!!

and also another update. this has big dent in one corner which i did not see before. so maybe some cold solder?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message:
"checked <SIGNAL>PP5VS0_BOOT</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C7520</CAPACITOR> pin 1 measures 5v but on pin 2 i got 9.80v!!!!"
That's absolutely correct.
Google may know something about what a bootstrap capacitor is; just ask him...

"Did you check for USB activity?"
???

"big dent in one corner"
Broken solder/trace under some BGA chip can be a nightmare...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message: all other s0 rails are good. not sure where to start looking?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message: Sounds like broken traces/cracked balls under the CPU or some chip. Definitely a time waster

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v - 0a no power?
threads.message: far. probably wrap it up & seal it.
